Abstract: Bridge column recalls remarkable bridge game played in 1917 in Constantinople harbor, to determine whether crew of US gunboat Scorpion would be interned by Turks or their German allies; captain, Herbert Babbitt, challenged Turkish minister, Talat Pasha, to rubber, with ship as stake; Babbitt won, and crew got its wish to remain in Turkish waters until end of war (M)
Snippet: Bridge column recalls remarkable bridge game played in 1917 in Constantinople harbor, to determine whether crew of US gunboat Scorpion would be interned by Turks or their German allies; captain, Herbert Babbitt, challenged Turkish minister, Talat ...
LeadParagraph: The most remarkable bridge game of the past century, or indeed the millennium, occurred in 1917 in the Turkish harbor of Constantinople, now Istanbul. An American gunboat, the Scorpion, was attached to the American Embassy there, and it was boarded by the Turks, who were German allies, when the United States entered World War I.

Headline.Main: The Only Naval Engagement Ever Won at the Card Table
Headline.PrintHeadline: BRIDGE; The Only Naval Engagement Ever Won at the Card Table
